author: pcgeek86

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: Should it output a warning if no subject?

comments.author: pcgeek86
comments.body: Hmm, good thought but my vote would be no.

comments.author: BitteringAgent
comments.body: Now that I think about it.  It should work like any other email application where there is a warning for no subject.  So there should be a warning, but also there should be a -Force to push past the warning of having no subject.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @BitteringAgent `-force` wouldn't be needed as a warning is just informational

comments.author: BitteringAgent
comments.body: Ah, I haven't dealt with too many cmdlets with warnings other than maybe doing a remote session into Exchange Online.  Thanks.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Missing Subject is a very bad practice. By default, we must ask for it to present. Maybe add `-IgnoreSubject`?

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: Another option is to prompt and allow `-force`

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: restarted mac tests due to random failure.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: I agree with @iSazonov , but prefer @SteveL-MSFT 's proposal to fix the issue.

comments.author: dantraMSFT
comments.body:
I think a better user experience would be to leave Subject as mandatory and place it in a 'Subject' parameter set.  Add a -NoSubject switch and place it in a 'NoSubject' parameter set, then set the default parameter set to 'Subject'.
This ensures the best practice is the default, avoids having to use an ambiguous -Force switch while still requiring an explicit choice to send without an subject.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: @pcgeek86 comments haven't been addressed in a long time.  At some point, if comments are not addressed, I'll close the PR.

title: Cmdlets: Set -Subject parameter to non-mandatory on Send-MailMessage command
